Facebook       More…                    Share         Get link         Facebook         Twitter         Pinterest         Email         Other Apps                March 30, 2012       Football      Ok, so it wouldn't be my blog if I did not mention my passion for football.  I have always like football but about 5 years ago was asked to join a fantasy football league with some "guys" at work.  I was the only female in the league, didn't know what I was doing but ended up in the playoffs.  I didn't win but I was hooked.  I went on to create my own fantasy football league but only for women.  It was so much fun.  We are going on our 4th year and all of us anxiously await football season.  Here is a picture of my All Girl Fantasy League from our first year. THE BALTIMORE SUN      Baseball Chicago White Sox -- Optioned P Robert Ellis, C Chris Tremie, IF Olmedo Saenz and IF Chris Snopek to Triple-A Nashville. Optioned P Mike Bertotti and OF Jimmy Hurst to Double-A Birmingham. Los Angeles Dodgers -- Optioned OF Roger Cedeno and SS Juan Castro to Triple-A Albuquerque; P Jesus Martinez and 2B Miguel Cairo to Double-A San Antonio; and P Roberto Duran and IF Willis Otanez to Single-A Vero Beach. Will send SS Wilton Guerrero from Albuquerque to San Antonio. Will send SS Mike Metcalfe from San Antonio to Vero Beach. St. Louis Cardinals -- Agreed to terms with IF Manuel Lee and IF Luis Rivera on minor-league contracts.    Seattle Mariners -- Signed P Bobby Ayala, P Jeff Nelson (Catonsville High, Catonsville CC), P Derek Lowe , P Shawn Estes, IF Giomar Guevara and OF Darren Bragg to one-year contracts. Renewed the contracts of P Tim Davis and P Bill Risley. Texas Rangers -- Optioned P Mark Brandenberg to Triple-A Oklahoma City; and P Kerry Lacy, P Jerry Martin, P Ritchie Moody and SS Guillermo Mercedes to Double-A Tulsa. Moody will be placed on the disabled list and stay in Florida for extended spring training . Colleges New Mexico -- Announced that Don Flanagan will, indeed, coach women's basketball. Flanagan had accepted the job April 7, then reneged, saying coaching would take away from time with his family.  Texas-San Antonio -- Named Tim Carter men's basketball coach and signed him to a three-year contract. Weber State -- Signed men's basketball coach Ron Abegglen to a seven-year contract. Hockey Montreal Canadiens -- Returned RW Chris Murray to AHL Fredericton.  New York Islanders -- Recalled C Chris Taylor from IHL Denver. Recalled G Eric Fichaud from QMJHL Chicoutimi. Washington Capitals -- Sent RW Pat Peake and RW Martin Gendron to AHL Portland.      Copyright

Capital Gazette wins special Pulitzer Prize citation for coverage of newsroom shooting that killed five           News    Oakland Mills grade changes investigated     Rick Belz and Tricia Bishop THE BALTIMORE SUN      Howard County school system officials said yesterday that they have been investigating improper grade changes at Oakland Mills High School after it was discovered a student's marks were altered - without teacher authorization - to make him eligible to play football. Results are expected as soon as this afternoon, said assistant superintendent Roger L. Plunkett, who's heading the inquiry. Oakland Mills forfeited seven regular-season victories and its first-round state playoff berth Nov. 13, and soon after football coach and athletic director Ken Hovet was placed on administrative leave with pay. "You cannot have a student getting a grade change without documentation that work has been done and some attempt has to be made to involve the teacher," Plunkett said, adding that forms must be completed that involve the principal.    According to Plunkett, principal Marshall Peterson reported last week that a player should have been declared academically ineligible at the start of the season. However, two of the student's grades were changed in late August, and he was allowed to join the rest of the team at practice. The player, who transferred to Oakland Mills in the middle of last year, played sparingly in five games. A failing grade given by teacher Tim Dahle, who left the school in June, was changed after being authorized by Peterson for acceptable academic reasons, Plunkett said. Peterson could not be reached yesterday for comment. "A principal has the right to make a grade change based upon teacher performance," Plunkett said. But a second change to a grade from a drama class taught by Stacie Lanier was "very suspect," Plunkett said. It was that change that ended Oakland Mills' season.  Lanier, who also is no longer at the Columbia school, said: "I haven't approved or signed a student's grade change form since ending my employment July 1, 2003." Lanier added that she has "consulted with an attorney and I wish to be cooperative, but I am operating under his advice. I hope this gets cleared up as soon as possible." Howard County regulations require a student to maintain at least a 2.0 grade point average and have no failing grades from the prior semester to participate in athletics. Patti Caplan, spokeswoman for the county school system, said that student records must be kept in a secure room with limited key access - that the principal (or designee) and registrar must be the only personnel who have keys.  Howard County school system guidelines state that "grade changes on a student's permanent record card are to be made by the registrar only. The person requesting the grade change must complete a grade change form which states the course name and number and the reason for the grade change. Parents should be notified of the grade change. The principal [or designee] will sign off on the grade change before the registrar makes the change." The current investigation started when Dahle, a technology education teacher, complained to Plunkett early in September that a former student whom he had failed in a spring class was playing football. Because that technology education class was not offered in summer school, the student could not have made up the class and Dahle wondered how he could be participating. Dahle, who said he first went to Peterson but never got a response, said that Plunkett took "two to three weeks to get back to me." Plunkett said he did try to respond to Dahle quickly, but that the two were playing "phone tag." He eventually reached Dahle. "When he did, he [Plunkett] said the player was legitimately on the team," Dahle said. "He told me everything was fine, but I knew it wasn't true," said Dahle, a retired Anne Arundel teacher who worked one year at Oakland Mills as a temporary teacher. Dahle said he then contacted school board member Sandra French, who forwarded him to Mark Blom, the school system's chief of staff. "I talked to Mr. Blom's assistant on the phone and a few days after that I heard the team forfeited its season," Dahle said. Dahle also said that Hovet contacted him in late August about whether the football player could make up the work and get the grade changed. "I told him no," said Dahle. "He [Hovet] then told me that he had nothing to do with this, that Marshall [Peterson] told him to put the kid on the team." Hovet declined to comment. Blom credited Dahle with triggering the investigation, but said that other information beyond what he had reported was uncovered and that caused the player to be declared ineligible. "We went beyond what he reported," Blom said. Plunkett said that last spring's report cards from all students participating in extracurricular activities are being reviewed at Oakland Mills. "We could do spot checks elsewhere," Plunkett said. "I hope this grade changing is not rampant. We don't want a witch hunt."      Copyright

BREAKING NEWS Sears sues former CEO, claiming he stripped $2 billion in assets as it headed to bankruptcy     News    MIDWEST WOMEN`S TEAMS READY TO TIP OFF THE SEASON     Mark Shapiro CHICAGO TRIBUNE      Chicago State made progress last season, tripling its victory total with a 6-22 record after going 2-26 in 1989-90. Although most of last season`s team is gone, second-year coach Mike Clark thinks the Cougars ''will be able to accomplish many goals that we were not able to reach last year.'' Only three players return, and the the Cougars` two top scorers-Seanta Hill (14 points a game) and Rhegheae Tate are among the departed. Center Latrice Robinson, whose 12.8 rebounds per game ranked third in Division I, will be asked to improve on her 7.8 points-per-game scoring average. Starting forward Debbie Scott averaged 11 points per game last season, and reserve forward Camille Wells averaged 5.8.    Clark will bank on strong contributions from some of the 10 newcomers. ''I am very satisfied with the results of my first recruiting campaign,'' he said. ''For the most part, I signed the players I wanted most.'' Four new players come from Detroit`s Cass Tech High School. Senior center/forward Robyn Williams, who`s 6-1, is likely to see a lot of playing time. Twin sisters Kassandra and Yolanda McGehee will also compete for playing time. Other newcomers include Sharleta Rogan, Tamara Ingram, Kim Allen, Precious Jackson, Toygena Canty, Angela Bryson and Molifenge Milhouse. Jackson, only 5 feet tall, set the all-time assist record at Ellsworth (Iowa) Community College. ''We`re expecting big things from Bryson this season,'' Clark said. Only 12 of the Cougars` 28 games will be at home. Sports    Tennis: W&M star gets indirect win vs.Clijsters; nice finish for Lafayette standouts (now with photo of Rams)             Sonny Dearth      We're tidying up some loose ends from recent tennis competition, with plenty of ties to Williamsburg ... We start at Wimbledon . William and Mary followers hopefully have heard by now that Megan Moulton-Levy, one of the best players in Tribe history, has earned a spot in her first "adult" Grand Slam event. I first heard of her when she qualified for junior draws in Slams before she came to W&M.; As a Colonial Athletic Association Player of the Year and as part of the 2007 NCAA tournament runner-up doubles tandem with Kat Zoricic, Moulton-Levy certainly lived up to the hype. Her personable nature and on-court speed and smarts won her plenty of fans. Besides, when you might be 5 feet tall and usually are smiling, it's hard to root against you.    Moulton-Levy nearly has cracked the top 100 in the Women's Tennis Association's individual doubles rankings. Getting in the main draw at the Big W certainly will boost that drive. She and Lindsay Lee-Waters, a longtime pro player who lives in suburban Atlanta (Dunwoody, Ga.), teamed up to win two qualifying matches on grass in Roehampton, England -- they save the Wimbledon courts for the main draw. The second victory, a 6-7 (6-8), 6-4, 8-6 triumph against Russians Nina Bratchikova and Valeria Savinykh, was dramatic enough. But the first triumph came against a better-known name. Moulton-Levy and Lee-Waters (call 'em the Fighting Hyphens!) initially won 6-3, 6-3 against Anna Tatishvili of the former Soviet republic of Georgia and left-hander Arantxa Rus of the Netherlands.  Yes, the same Arantxa Rus that bounced Kim Clijsters at Roland Garros. Sure, Clijsters had an off day, but still ... think about it! This is just two degrees of separation. If you went to McCormack-Nagelsen Tennis Center earlier this decade, you probably saw somebody who beat somebody this spring who beat Kim Clijsters this spring. The first-round match for the Hyphens later this week will be against a couple of players who have had modest tour success: Romania's Alexandra Dulgheru and Slovakia's Magdalena Rybarikova. --Also, another former CAA Player of the Year is in a Wimbledon doubles draw: 2001 honoree Frank Moser of VCU . He and fellow German meet Lleyton Hewitt and Peter Luczak in the first round.  -------------------------  HIGH SCHOOL HURRAH And now we go to Virginia Tech, where Lafayette senior Chris Ford and junior Cole Fairbanks ended their season with a flourish a week-and-a-half ago. Before the Group AA postseason, Jamestown boys coach Bob Artis said he thought the doubles competition would be unpredictable. He was accurate, with the Eagles' Miles Neilson and Sam Ross taking the district crown but falling in the Region I tournament final to Ford and Fairbanks. The Lafayette tennis teams -- boys and girls -- have spent so much time in the shadow of Jamestown's squads that it's amazing that that the Rams can catch a tan. But Ford and Fairbanks made sure Lafayette had a little time in the sun. Showing no stage fright in their first state appearance, they rolled past another regional champion team, John James and Scottie Taylor from E.C. Glass High in Lynchburg, 6-3, 6-1 to reach the championship match. Not bad, considering James and Taylor had been 22-0 for the season. Getting to the final, the Rams would've had the right to feel like lambs -- of the sacrificial variety. It's hard to describe how dominant the Salem Spartans were this year, but to say they owned Group AA would be an understatement. Future Radford University player Patrick O'Keefe took his fourth straight state singles championship, losing all of one game of the 25 he played in that bracket. Then he led the Spartans to their first team championship since 1994. After three days of dominant Salem tennis, the last piece of the puzzle was the doubles crown. O'Keefe was teaming with Will Drougas, who figures to play quite highly in the lineup for a solid Division III team in Ohio, Case Western Reserve, next season. Completing the triple crown didn't figure to be a problem, since the Spartans had made winning 6-0, 6-0 relatively common. But Ford and Fairbanks wouldn't go down without a tussle. The one advantage they had was being much fresher. Since traveling west, they had played one official match (the win over E.C. Glass). O'Keefe? Because of his and Salem's success, he was completing his third day in a row of playing at least two matches in a day, and he and Drougas were in their third match of that particular Saturday. Juvenile & Domestic Relations Judge Jeff Fairbanks, a former W&M; player who is Cole's dad, said the Region I champs "hung in there in spite of losing the first set 6-1. There were several games where Lafayette would get up 40-love and couldn't close out the game. "In the second set, Lafayette broke Drougas and was up 4-1, and by that time the sun had come back out and it looked like Drougas might falter. If they could have gone to a third set, anything was possible. "Cole hit a couple of overheads out of the park and Chris hit a forehand down the line to give LHS the lead. The coach from Salem came over at the break and there was a lot of discussion. Unfortunately when they came out, Lafayette couldn't hold them." So the Spartans won 6-1, 6-4, but not before the Rams had impressed their fans and some new folks in the New River Valley. Lehigh Valley Top Workplaces 2019: Winners, awards ceremony pics and more           News    Hustle plays energize Liberty's rally to victory ** Kahler's homer and shoestring catch define effort against Allen. ** District 11 Softball     Keith Groller Of The Morning Call THE MORNING CALL      Michele Laubach asked her Liberty High softball team for "extra effort" in its District 11 3A opener against visiting Allen on Tuesday. The Hurricanes took their coach's request to heart in a come-from-behind 4-2 victory. Pitcher Laura Jaxheimer was injured twice while tagging out runners during home-plate collisions, yet still finished the game. Left fielder Kara Kahler homered and made a diving catch in left that turned into a critical double play.  Amanda Kensecki roared back from an early strikeout to get two singles, including the infield hit that sparked a three-run fourth inning. "We had the extra effort we've been asking for all season," Laubach said after her No. 7-seeded, 15-7 team earned a quarterfinal-round trip to Pottsville on Thursday. Allen, looking to continue its remarkable turnaround season, took a 1-0 lead in the top of the fourth on Justine Kiechel's RBI single. But the Hurricanes came back in the bottom of the fourth when Kensecki singled, stole second and moved to third on a sacrifice bunt.  Jaxheimer singled off the right forearm of Chicks' pitcher Erin Kirkpatrick to score one run. Katlyn Snyder's RBI double made it 2-0, and Meggan Oates capped the inning with another RBI hit. Two Liberty errors helped Allen (10-11) get a run back in the top of the fifth, but Jaxheimer covered the plate and held on after colliding for the second time in three innings with the Chicks' Tess Mravlag. The first time Mravlag was trying to score on a wild pitch; the second time on an overthrow. But both times she was tagged out by Jaxheimer after catcher Lauren Malacsics retrieved the ball. "They don't make them any tougher than Laura," Laubach said. "She hurt her mouth the first time and her ankle the second time. She's sore, but she'll be all right."  Although not feeling well, Jaxheimer finished the game and got a big lift from Kahler in the top of the sixth. Kahler's home run gave Liberty a 4-2 lead in the top of the fifth. But the Chicks, who stranded six runners, wouldn't go away. Karla Cardona singled to left to start the sixth. Gabby Mink followed with a sinking line drive to left. Kahler stretched out for a shoestring catch, got to her feet and threw to first base for a rally-killing double play. Had the ball skipped past her, the game might have been tied. "I want our outfielders to be aggressive," Laubach said. "All year, we've been pulling up short and the ball has still been going by us. I'd rather see us go all out on a ball like that. If it goes by, it goes by." Kahler simply said bye-bye to Allen's comeback bid. "I saw it and knew I could get it, so I went for it," Kahler said. "When I made the catch, I saw their runner was already at second, so I knew I could get the double play." Kahler admitted that Liberty started the game "a little flat," perhaps a carryover from Saturday's dismal 9-1 loss to Parkland in the Lehigh Valley Conference title game. Now, the team eagerly awaits its trip to Pottsville. "We're looking forward instead of behind us," Kahler, a junior, said. "We want to learn from our mistakes, but not dwell on the bad things." Allen coach Scott Didra, whose team was just 2-15 in 2003, hated to leave the dugout and a memorable season. "I'm going to miss these kids," Didra said. "I'm going to miss just being around them. I can't put into words how far they've come this year." About Us/À propos de nous   Les Lions de St. Lawrence sont l’hôte d’un camp de basketball depuis 1997. Plus de 8000 jeunes athlètes ont participé à un de nos Méga Camps ou encore à nos Camps Spécialisés et plusieurs de ces jeunes reviennent année après année.  Plusieurs de nos entraîneurs sont même d’anciens campeurs !  Qu’est‐ce qui nous rend différents? Les participants, en plus d’améliorer leurs performances en basket‐ball, améliorent aussi leur anglais, car l’utilisation de l’anglais est encouragée par le jeu durant tout leur séjour.  Nous avons de grandes exigences pour nos entraîneurs; ils aiment être avec les jeunes et ont tous une grande expérience de ce sport, soit en tant qu’athlète ou entraîneur. De plus, ils suivent une formation, bonifiant cette expérience, afin de maximiser la transmission de leur passion à vos enfants. Finalement, ils leur inculquent la confiance en soi et la satisfaction de travailler et réussir en équipe.  The St. Lawrence Lions have been hosting basketball camps since 1997. Over 8000 young athletes have participated in our mega camps and our specialized camps; many of them coming back year after year. Most of our coaches are actually past campers. What makes us different? As an English speaking camp, we encourage through games and positive reinforcement the use of English and our athletes are rewarded for their efforts during the week. We also work hard to hire coaches who love kids and are enthusiastic about life.  They are hand‐picked to build your child’s confidence, teach great fundamentals, play and make a difference. Sign up for free             Home  Categories  Test Matches                      29 votes | 1982 views           Chamdimal ton matched by Aussie response: 3rd Test, Day 2 (SSC)   Dinesh Chandimal's superb hundred pushed Sri Lanka's first-innings total to 355 after they were reduced to 26 for five on the first morning.  Steven Smith and Shaun Marsh scored unbeaten half-centuries as Australia reached 141 for one wicket, trail Sri Lanka by 214 runs to have the match finely poised. Sri Lanka have already won the series 2-0.  Australia 141 for 1 (S Marsh 64*, Smith 61*) trail Sri Lanka 355 (Chandimal 132, De Silva 129, Starc 5-63, Lyon 3-110) by 214 runs. LIFETIME RECORD:  33-34-1           YEAR 4- 2000  Show Me the Money got off to a slow start and never was
      able to recover.  In the first six weeks they only had one win to
      show for their effort and were their Division cellar-dweller for the
      entire season, until the final week, when they pulled 1/2 game ahead of
      C&D to escape from the bottom of their Division.  REGULAR SEASON RECORD:  7-9-1   YEAR 3- 1999  This was the year Show Me the Money finally made the
        playoffs. Winners of their Division, they started off slowly with a .500
        record through the first six weeks.  Embarking on a winning streak,
        Show Me led their Division by Week 10 and never relinquished the lead. 
        They finished sixth overall and will pick seventh  in the next
        draft.  REGULAR SEASON RECORD:  11-6    YEAR 2- 1998  This team appeared to be out of it all year until the
        end of the season.   After embarking one a three game win sreak,
        they pulled even with the rest of the Division in Week #14, but
        collapsed the rest of the way to finish one game behind the Undertakers,
        who won the Division. REGULAR SEASON RECORD:  7-10    YEAR 1- 1997  Show Me the Money, coached by Michael Goydish, had an
        exciting 1997 season, just missing the playoffs in Week #17 with a loss.   
        Half way through the year they had a 4-5 record, and they kept pace in
        the second half finishing with an 8-9 record.  They stayed in the
        hunt all year long until C & D Touchdown Makers beat them in the
        final week, eleminating them from a playoff seeding. REGULAR SEASON RECORD:  8-9

Toggle Newsletter Search Facebook Twitter Pinterest WhatsApp Culture 'Sports Illustrated' Swimsuit Issue Editor: Women Should Be Just as Respected in a Bikini as They Are in a Turtleneck By Leah Bourne February 13, 2018 12:15 pm Facebook Twitter Pinterest WhatsApp Pinterest PHOTO: Ben Watts for Sports Illustrated Danielle Herrington is the third African American woman to be featured on SI 's Swimsuit Issue cover. The Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue and the #MeToo movement at first sound about as disparate as they come, but last February, amid the climate of Donald Trump and the simultaneous rise of a new wave of feminism, the magazine’s editor MJ Day and her all-female staff began planning for the 2018 edition with one theme top-of-mind: changing the preconceived notions about women, including those who happen to enjoy wearing bikinis. “We were having these conversations months ago, before Harvey Weinstein , about how women are perceived in the media, how women are perceived in the workplace,” Day told Glamour. “It was all very conscious.” Pinterest Day might not have set out to create S.I. ’s #MeToo edition a year ago, but she might as well have. The Swimsuit Issue that landed on newsstands today features 18-year-old Danielle Herrington on the cover, the third African American woman in the magazine’s history. It includes a nude spread shot by female photographer Taylor Ballantyne, supported by an all-female crew, in which models Paulina Porizkova and Sailor Brinkley have written words on their bodies like artist and natural, a nod to being more than just a body. Model Myla Dalbesio has penned an essay for the issue on why it is perfectly OK to pose in the magazine and believe in feminist ideals. To understand why this issue is making such waves, it’s important to look at the magazine’s history. The Swimsuit Issue made its debut in 1964 as a way to fill S.I. ’s winter months, a particularly slow period in the sporting world. Before long, it had mainstreamed the bikini, launched the careers of supermodels ranging from Christie Brinkley to Kathy Ireland, all while the brand grew, spawning everything from a subscription video service to an apparel collection. Loading View on Instagram Interestingly, the magazine has always been run by women. First, by Julie Campbell, and now by Day, who has been at the magazine for 20 years, and at the top of the masthead since 2014 (her first job at the magazine involved sorting through the estimated 30,000 bikinis that get submitted by designers for each issue). Still, while the magazine has become renowned for featuring beautiful women in itty-bitty bathing suits, shot in exotic locales, it has hardly been seen as inclusive of a wide range of beauty ideals throughout most of its tenure, a point not lost on Day. “I fought for size inclusivity even as a junior member of the team, and for whatever reason it wasn’t received at the time,” Day said “I did cast a plus-size model in my first year, and when she showed up, she had dropped five sizes from when I had cast her. It’s been a struggle.” Change, though, started to trickle into the pages of the magazine, starting in 2012. “From the moment Kate Upton was on the cover, we started a cultural discussion on size because she was not the standard,” Day says. “Kate Upton is perfect, and I know it sounds silly now, but it symbolized something. Women like Chrissy Teigen, Ashley Graham, Robyn Lawley, they do too. I just wish it had happened sooner.” Day, with this issue, hopes that she can shepherd further change in the industry by promoting the talents of women behind the scenes—as photographers, writers, and directors of photography, a role that model Robyn Lawley played at a shoot. “Women are usually confined to one category—like she’s the bombshell,” Day says. “But she’s also a mom, a businesswoman, so much more. It’s frustrating. Even I’m perceived one way because I’m the editor of the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue. But I’m a nerd, a mom, I love puppies, I care for elderly parents.” Beyond inclusivity, the #MeToo movement has also shed a light on the mistreatment many models have faced within the industry. Day says watching from the sidelines as famous photographers have been brought down amid accusations they’ve sexually harassed or abused models has felt foreign to her in relationship to how she's always run shoots. “Maybe because it’s just six of us full-time [women on the staff], but as a group we have always been sensitive to creating a safe space for models,” Day says. “These women are my colleagues, I’m close with them, and I respect them. At the bare minimum, models should be treated as people. It’s confusing to me that people think otherwise.” With all the changes happening, Day wants her audience to know that the magazine's sexy appeal isn’t going anywhere. “You have a choice as a woman as to how you want to dress,” Day says. “And just because you aren’t covered head to toe doesn’t mean you are inviting yourself to touched inappropriately, or to be judged, or to be thought less of. There is a real misconception that if you have feminist views, you have to dress a certain way. For the life of me I can’t understand why some people think someone in a triangle thong shouldn’t be respected but a woman in a turtleneck should be.” It’s a sentiment that led Day to share a photo of herself in a bikini a little less than a year ago on Instagram. After all, if she was going to talk the talk, she might as well walk the walk. Loading View on Instagram “Even when I was lifeguard and at my peak level of fitness, I didn’t love being in a bathing suit, which I know is a funny thing for me to say,” she said. “It was definitely a terrifying moment, I felt vulnerable, but it gave me a better sense of what women put themselves through in the industry. Even women who still fit a certain standard get ripped apart. In end, it was really liberating. All women should be able to rock a bathing suit and feel good about it and I wanted to send the message that we are celebrating women of all different shapes and sizes. If you are a model or you aren’t a model, you should certainly be able to feel good about yourself in a bikini. That’s really what this issue is about too.” Keywords: sports illustrated swimsuit issue MeToo magazine cover Facebook Twitter Pinterest WhatsApp Get Our Newsletter Your daily dose of the latest in fashion, beauty, and entertainment — delivered straight to your inbox. There's a lot of value in a "set and forget" QB that goes underappreciated by many imo... especially in smaller leagues like mine, with Wilson on my team I had the luxury of going almost the full year with only 1 QB on my roster... which just frees up at least 1 roster spot (if not more) for some lottery tickets. I'm the only person in my 10-team league that currently has only 1 QB, while five teams have 3+ QB's (two of those teams have 4!!!) and not so coincidentally I don't think any of those teams have a single valuable RB/WR on their bench... and then they curse the fantasy gods for their "bad injury luck" when it's just an inevitable occurrence that should be prepared for. Instead they're foolishly crossing their fingers that their team is somehow immune to it. Like, you seriously thought all your starters would just play all 16 games like it's no big deal? Obviously that injury stuff can happen to QB's too as we saw this year, but it's nowhere near the same level of risk.  Anyway, I'm ranting and getting off-topic as a lot of that is irrelevant to my opinion on Luck lol. I personally would avoid Luck at this point but I wouldn't blame others for chasing that ceiling he may still have. I just think it's unlikely he reaches that ceiling, while it's very possible he just never again reaches that "elite" value that everyone wants from him. Though to be fair, I've always been a little low on him his whole career relative to the rest of the community.  10-team standard, 18-man rosters (plus K/D) 1 QB | 2 RB | 2 WR | 1 TE | 1 FLEX | 1 K | 1 D  10-3, 2nd (AP: 88-29 / 75.2%, 1st) Wk 14 QF - BYE ||| Wk 15 SF - W ||| Wk 16 CP - L    QB: Russ , Brady RB: Gurley , DJ , Bell , Chubb, Breida, Foreman, Ito, Ware WR: Nuk , AJG , Evans, Keenan, Diggs, Watkins TE: Kelce , Gronk K: Ghost D: (stream)   2019 Picks: 1.09, 3.09, 4.09, 5.09 2020 Picks: 1st, 3rd, 4th, 5th 2021 Picks: 1st, 3rd, 4th, 5th              CK_   Role Player  Posts:  355  Joined: Sun Dec 18, 2016 9:20 pm     Re: When to draft luck?    Quote    Post by CK_ » Tue Feb 13, 2018 3:07 pm  thebeast wrote: ↑ Tue Feb 13, 2018 1:40 pm  CK_ wrote: ↑ Tue Feb 13, 2018 9:44 am Where is Garoppolo being drafted in 1qb?  I assume he is inflated due to his recent contract. He seems like a better buy right now.  Luck is a very smart guy and is being devalued by way too many. He knows the best path to his success and that is a QB1 in the NFL.  Maybe you have the chance of snagging Jimmy G in the 7/8th and then grabbing Luck in the 8/9th. I would always grab a stud QB a round earlier in the later rounds than their ADP suggests. There is literally no value in grabbing a QB in the 3rd to 4th rounds. So much value and top tier QBness can be had in rounds 7-10. Romo 13/14, Cam 15, Ryan 16, and Wentz 17.  I personally can't wait to have Garoppolo and Luck for next year. Keep on devalueing cause ill keep on scooping up studs. Hmmm, Romo in the 13/14th seems a little early to me. Apologies I meant those years those QBs were easy to get in rounds 7-10. GIFT VOUCHERS         TBR Air Filter and Bracket Kit                      Add To Wishlist    Unlike paper filters, "Open Cell" Polyurethane Foam is wetted with specially developed filter oil. This "sticky" filter oil is suspended in the path of the dirty air on the web-like cell structure of the foam making it impossible for dirt to pass through the filter without sticking to the strands. As the outer strands become loaded with dirt particles, the wetted strands down stream start trapping dirt, allowing the entire thickness to be utilized. This prevents surface loading or air restriction for 80% of the service life of the air filter element. When the filter is sufficiently dirty, it can be easily washed, re-oiled, and re-used. � Easy to install � Includes mounting bracket to replace stock air box � Made from top quality materials for the serious rider. � Surface area is greater than stock for improved airflow. � Dual-density filter element helps keep harmful dust and debris out of the engine providing improved performance and longer engine life. � Easy to clean and maintain. Varsity Coaches         2019 Panther Coaches & Staff    Varsity Coaches    Mark Fleetwood, Head Coach  Coach Mark Fleetwood is in his 2nd year at Huntsville High. His first year at Huntsville High, Coach Fleetweed led the Panthers to the first round of the Alabama High School Association State playoffs - the first time since 2013.  Additionally, nine of Coach Fleetwood's seniors class of 2018 signed to play college football.  He comes to Huntsville High from Peachtree Ridge High School in Suwanee, Ga. where his teams made the play-offs five out of six years compiling a 41-27 record.  Coach Fleetwood grew up in Decatur, Ga. where he attended Lakeside High School and played for the legendary Wayman Creel. Fleetwood attended the University of South Carolina from 1979-1983 and was three-year starter as a placekicker where he earned a B.S. degree in Distributive Education. He also has a Masters degree in Education Administration from Jacksonville State University.  Fleetwood was a free agent selection by the Dallas Cowboys in 1984. Coach Fleetwood is entering his 32 nd year in the coaching profession. His career has included coaching stints at Jacksonville State University, Troy University, University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, Habersham Central High School, The Citadel, Cartersville High School and Peachtree Ridge High School.  Coach Fleetwood is married to former Kimberly Gilmore of Eufaula, Alabama and they have a daughter, Irelan, who is a graduate of  Huntsville High, class of 2018.    Chris Hancock, Defensive Coordinator/Linebackers  Chris Hancock has been coaching for 16 years and is beginning his 2nd year at Huntsville High School. He began his coaching career at Riverton Middle School as a football, softball, and baseball coach for three years. He spent the next 9 seasons as a defensive line coach, defensive coordinator and head football coach at Buckhorn High School and was an assistant coach for the 2005 State Runner-up Bucks football team.  He spent one season as defensive coordinator at Sparkman High School before taking the Columbia High School head football coaching position where he spent three years. He is a graduate of Jacksonville State University and played for the Gamecock football program under Bill Burgess. He teaches PLTW Engineering at Huntsville High School. He is married to Susan and they have a daughter Macy.            Terrance Young - Corners  Coach Young graduated from Munford High School and earned both a Bachelor’s and Master’s Degree in Mathematics Education from Alabama A&M University. He is beginning his 18th year at HHS and is currently teaching Geometry. He is also the Head Track and Field Coach. He is married to his high school sweetheart, Alecia McNeal, from Talladega, Alabama. They have three boys; twins, Terrant and Terrell (14 yrs. old) and Tyson (10 yrs. old).            Tyler Johnson - Offensive Coordinator/Offensive Line Coach   Coach Johnson enters his 4th year at Huntsville High.  Coach Johnson is a 2008 Huntsville High School graduate and is very happy to be back "home".  He previously coached at Columbia High School for two years where he was the offensive line coach and offensive coordinator for one of those years.  He received his undergraduate degree from the University of Alabama in Secondary Education in 2013.  In 2014, Tyler married his wife Amber and they have a dog named Dixie.              John Barnes - Running Backs  Coach Barnes enters his 3rd year teaching and coaching at Huntsville High.  He previously coached at Columbia High School for two years where he coached wide receivers and defensive backs.  He received his Bachelor's degree in Political Science from the University of Alabama, his teaching certificate through Athens State University and his Master's degree in Social Studies Education from the University of West Alabama.  While at the University of Alabama, Coach Barnes worked in the Athletic Departmet for the football team assisting with coach's film, recruiting film and football equipment.  While there, he was an integral member of three National Championship teams and two southeastern Conference Championship teams.  Coach Barnes is a 2008 graduate of Huntsville High School.         Ty Cox - Tackles  Coach Cox is entering his 2nd year at Huntsville High School teaching and coaching football.  Previously, Coach Cox served as offensive coordinator and offensive line coach New Hope High School for three years.  While attending the University of Alabama he served under Coach Saban as a student assistant for the football team for three years.  Coach Cox is orginally from Russellville, AL where he played for three state championships, was a team captain and was voted offensive team captain by his teammates.  He is also the son of Alabama High School Hall of Fame football Coach Don Cox.                                                             © 2019 SportsEngine, The Home of Youth Sports

(Houston, TX)  --  The Timbers will play Saturday in Houston.  Portland is coming off a 2-1 victory Sunday over Vancouver.  The Blazers are tied for fourth in the MLS Western Conference standings with 30 points.  The Houston Dynamo are in third with 32 points.  Winger Dairon Asprilla and left back Vytas are questionable for the match.  In other news, the team officially acquired New Zealand international Bill Tuiloma. Skip to first row site navigation  Skip to second row site navigation  Skip to news entries  Skip to archive page  Skip to double wide sidebar  Skip to tabbed sidebar  Skip to left sidebar                    Home  Classifieds  Subscribe  Advertising Info  Forms  About Us  Email Us          Football: Bulldoggs move up to No. 8 in state rankings  MainStreetNewsSports              RSS Feed   Email Alerts         Top Stories  JCCHS  CHS  MCHS  BCHS  JHS  EJCHS  WBHS  AHS  BCA  Auto Racing  Other  Special Sect            Football: Bulldoggs move up to No. 8 in state rankings    Posted by Chris Bridges    Wednesday, September 13. 2017    Comments (0)      The Winder-Barrow High School football team was off this past week but still managed to move up a spot in the most recent GHSA Class AAAAAA poll. The Bulldoggs are now eighth in the new poll released by Georgia High School Football Daily. WBHS (3-0) returns to action this Friday on the road against Loganville High School. This season marks the first time since 1994 that the WBHS football team has been ranked in the top 10. Tucker High School remains the No. 1 team in Class AAAAAA followed by Lee County, Coffee, Mays, Harrison, Northside Warner Robins, WBHS, Douglas County and Allatoona. The top three teams remained unchanged while Mays and Harrison switched places. Douglas County and Allatoona are new to the top 10 this week while Lovejoy and Northgate fell out. skip to main | skip to sidebar                    Saturday, August 23, 2008         Football Season      Andrew Maxwell, above, is the quarterback for Midland High School. Apparently, he's really good at what he does. He's ranked in the top 11 quarterbacks in the country, and he's already committed to Michigan State for the fall of 2009. I look forward to watching him this season, and in the future. Who knows, he may be the next Eli Manning. Oh, and btw, this portrait was shot for the cover of our football tab. I'm not sure if it's "the one," but this is what I chose in my early stages of editing the shoot. Enjoy! Search Poetry Teatime                 World Cup Soccer Poetry    This Sunday is the World Cup final, with France and Croatia competing for the title of world champion in soccer! Soccer is the most popular sport in the world, played in over 200 countries. Whether you’ve watched every match of the World Cup or have never seen a soccer game in your life, today’s the day to learn more about the game and enjoy some soccer-themed poetry!   [This post contains Amazon affiliate links. When you click on those links to make purchases, Poetry Teatime receives compensation at no extra cost to you. Thank you!]  Games similar to soccer have been found in manuscripts and archaeological sites dating back at least 3,000 years, in areas as far apart as Ancient China and Medieval Europe. In the early days, the soccer “ball” could be made out of anything, from cloth stuffed with rocks to inflated animal bladders!  The game of soccer (also called “football” in many countries around the world) officially began in 1863 when England formed the Football Association and created rules for the game. Women also started playing soccer at around the same time in England, but they were not allowed to compete formally until the 20th century. Find out more about the history of soccer here from the FIFA World Cup website.  The World Cup tournament happens every four years. The participating countries change each time, since the team has to qualify to compete on a world level. This year, teams competed from five continents. All of the semi-finalists this year were teams from Europe (France, Croatia, Belgium, and England). The stakes are high, with each team competing for the glory of their home country. To find out more about the teams and key players, search “World Cup 2018” on Google for handy charts and graphs from Google.   If you want to celebrate with a World Cup-themed party, decorate by hanging up the flags of countries in the World Cup this year. Go back and watch the short highlight videos of games so far (found on Google under “World Cup 2018”). Be sure to choose a side—France or Croatia—for the final match!  You don’t want to miss out on these fun soccer-themed books, either. You can even make reading the poems a game! Grab a soccer ball and stand in a circle in an open space. After reading a poem, each person needs to pass the soccer ball across the circle to choose the next reader. Be sure to follow the rules of soccer, so no using arms or hands!  Soccer-Themed Poetry Books  Soccer Beat , by Sandra Gilbert Brug  Goodnight Soccer , by Michael Dahl  Booked , by Kwame Alexander (verse novel)  Fantastic Football Poems , edited by John Foster  Football Fever , edited by John Foster  Friendly Matches , by Allan Ahlberg  General Sports Books  The Fastest Game on Two Feet: And Other Poems about How Sports Began , by Alice Low  Let’s Play!: Poems About Sports and Games from Around the World , by Debjani Chatterjee  Score!: 50 Poems to Motivate and Inspire , by Charles Ghigna        Poetry Corner   Share this page:                   © 2019 Brave Writer

skip to main | skip to sidebar               Pages     Home    eCraft Videos    eCraft Settings Chart                    Thursday, June 30, 2011      A Non Sporty Card made from Sports Life!     I mentioned the other day that there is a category on the eCraft Sports Life SD card that is called Spectator & Awards.  Well in that category are all sorts of things that can be used for non-sporting events as well.    So for this card, I cut out the popcorn box and the soda.  On the popcorn box, I cut out all layers and colored in the words on the popcorn box with my Copics (again...be careful!).  The soda is cut with all layers.  For the background, I did some magic with my PSE 8 and some digi paper, graphic files, and fonts.  Love this card!  I am going to have to plan a special movie night for my DH so that I have an excuse to give him this card!  Tomorrow is a super simple card (or a set of 3) that I made using a single cut from Office Essentials and some FABULOUS new paper that I just got!        at 5:00 AM             Email This BlogThis! Sky Foot Ball     Previews, News, results          Accueil  Disclaimer  Terms and Conditions of Use  Contact us  Privacy Policy  CH01                    dimanche 19 janvier 2014        Monaco win at Toulouse to maintain pressure on PSG     12:55         Youngsters Layvin Kurzawa and substitute Lucas Ocampos scored to help Monaco move within two points of Ligue 1 leaders Paris St Germain in a 2-0 win at midtable Toulouse on Sunday. Kurzawa opened the scoring from close range in the 36th minute and Ocampos sealed the victory with a splendid overhead kick two minutes from time as Monaco moved up to 45 points from 21 games. Champions Paris St Germain can re-establish their five-point advantage if they beat sixth place Nantes at home later on Sunday (2000 GMT). "We have not played well after the winter break so I'm very happy with this victory. I hope that we're back on track," Monaco coach Claudio Ranieri told broadcaster beIN Sport. Monaco were second best throughout the first half but took the lead with their first chance when Kurzawa found the net from Geoffrey Kondogbia's low cross. The 21-year-old full back, playing his first season in the top-flight, has now scored in three consecutive away league games. Monaco upped the pace after the break and striker Radamel Falcao came close to scoring his first goal in two months when he skipped past goalkeeper Ali Ahamada, only to see midfielder Abel Aguilar clear his attempt on the goalline. The 19-year-old Ocampos, who had replaced Colombia international Falcao in the 68th minute, eventually wrapped it up with a superb finish from James Rodriguez's long cross.
